articles.headline: Work-Sharing May Help Companies Avoid Layoffs
articles.snippet: A new program aims to help employers avoid layoffs by reducing their workers’ hours and pay. For employees, state unemployment funds help make up the difference.
articles.abstract: A new program aims to help employers avoid layoffs by reducing their workers’ hours and pay. For employees, state unemployment funds help make up the difference.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN, Conn.  As companies struggle to make it from recession to recovery, many are turning to a novel but unheralded program that cuts their costs while sparing their workers’ jobs.

articles.headline: Investors Back in Market for British Real Estate
articles.snippet: Entrepreneurs are snapping up commercial real estate at a 75 percent markdown from top-of-the-market prices two years ago.
articles.abstract: Entrepreneurs are snapping up commercial real estate at a 75 percent markdown from top-of-the-market prices two years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nick Leslau, one of Britain’s wealthiest property entrepreneurs, got out of the market just before it turned down in 2007. Now he and a small but growing number of other investors say they think it is time to start buying again.

articles.headline: G.M. Insider Wants to Show He’s Tough Enough
articles.snippet: Fritz Henderson said that changes were coming at General Motors that would demonstrate his willingness to break from the past.
articles.abstract: Fritz Henderson said that changes were coming at General Motors that would demonstrate his willingness to break from the past.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Can the deeply ingrained culture of a 100-year-old company be transformed by an insider who has never worked anywhere else?

articles.headline: In Iran, an Iron Cleric, Now Blinking
articles.snippet: Though few suggest that Ayatollah Ali Khamenei’s hold on power is at risk, analysts say he has opened a fissure in the face of Islamic rule that may prove impossible to patch.
articles.abstract: Though few suggest that Ayatollah Ali Khamenei’s hold on power is at risk, analysts say he has opened a fissure in the face of Islamic rule that may prove impossible to patch.
articles.lead_paragraph: For two decades, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has remained a shadowy presence at the pinnacle of power in Iran, sparing in his public appearances and comments. Through his control of the military, the judiciary and all public broadcasts, the supreme leader controlled the levers he needed to maintain an iron if discreet grip on the Islamic republic.

articles.headline: U.S. to Confront, Not Board, North Korean Ships
articles.snippet: The new effort to intercept North Korean ships, and track them to their next port if they refuse inspection, is part of what officials described as “vigorous enforcement.”
articles.abstract: The new effort to intercept North Korean ships, and track them to their next port if they refuse inspection, is part of what officials described as “vigorous enforcement.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration will order the Navy to hail and request permission to inspect North Korean ships at sea suspected of carrying arms or nuclear technology, but will not board them by force, senior administration officials said Monday.

articles.headline: Tobacco Regulation Is Expected to Face a Free-Speech Challenge
articles.snippet: Congress would like to stop young people from smoking, but opponents say the marketing and advertising restrictions in the measure don’t abide by the First Amendment.
articles.abstract: Congress would like to stop young people from smoking, but opponents say the marketing and advertising restrictions in the measure don’t abide by the First Amendment.
articles.lead_paragraph: The marketing and advertising restrictions in the tobacco law that Congress passed last week are likely to be challenged in court on free-speech grounds. But supporters of the legislation say they drafted the law carefully to comply with the First Amendment.

articles.headline: Recount Offer Fails to Quell Political Tumult in Iran
articles.snippet: On a second day of huge demonstrations, the government placed tight restrictions on media coverage, especially by foreign journalists.
articles.abstract: On a second day of huge demonstrations, the government placed tight restrictions on media coverage, especially by foreign journalists.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN  Iran’s leaders failed on Tuesday to halt a second day of huge demonstrations against last week’s election results but, placed on the defensive, offered another concession to the sustained rage here, saying they would allow a limited recount.
